heading: archimedes gets a makeover
subheading: scientists are using modern technology to unlock the secrets of the only known copy of a 2,300-year-old text by the mathematician archimedes. by louise knapp.
author: wired staff
text: a new study of an ancient manuscript means that 2,300 years after archimedes ran naked through the streets of syracuse shouting "eureka!" scientists will finally discover exactly what the greek mathematician was bragging about. it's not that scholars don't have a clue about his theories written in the two treatises on floating bodies and method of mechanical theorems. after all, much of modern science is based on materials in those aged manuscripts.but thanks to the latest imaging technology being used on this third century b.c. manuscript, scientists will finally be able to read and study the whole thing.the manuscript outlines archimedes' explanation of the pulley, the fulcrum and the lever, and the physics of flotation -- why boats float -- the discovery that compelled his famous, gleeful, and immodest streak during which he exclaimed in greek, "i found it.""it's the only original archimedes manuscript. it's the eureka manuscript -– archimedes' brain in a box," said william noel, curator of the walters art gallery in baltimore. "it's the most reliable example of a 2,000-year-old dead genius. how much more important can you get than this? it's absolutely seminal -- it cuts right to the heart of his persona."deciphering the 174-page manuscript, however, is not an easy task. not only is the parchment in very poor condition, but the original text has been erased and the parchment recycled as a prayer book.scientists believe a scribe copied the manuscript in the 10th century from archimedes' original greek scrolls. some 200 years later, the text was erased by a monk who re-used the parchment, creating a twice-used parchment book known as a "palimpsest," a greek word meaning "scraped again.""if it had survived complete and been known in the italian renaissance, the history of mathematics would almost certainly have been different," wrote nigel wilson of the university of oxford and a member of the advisory group responsible for the conservation and publication of the archimedes manuscript, in an e-mail interview.once the restoration is complete, "we shall have a more intelligible text of the most important essay that archimedes wrote," wilson said.the original recycling process was painstaking. the original manuscript was taken apart and the original ink scraped off. the monk also cut the sheets in half, rotated the pages by 90 degrees and then reassembled the book.this type of recycling was very common in the 12th century. parchment, made from animal skin, was often in short supply and very expensive. also, religious tracts -- containing exorcisms and prayers for the sick -- were all the rage, while advanced treatises on mathematical theories didn't exactly make the top 40 charts.a danish scholar, johan ludvig heiberg, discovered the archimedes palimpsest in 1907, and was able to make out parts of the text by using regular sunlight and a magnifying glass. heiberg published his research, and his text became the standard edition that school children sweat over today."heiberg focused on recovering simply the text. we are bound to gain a lot of insight from looking at the mathematical diagrams that heiberg neglected.... there is no question that the text is going to be changed dramatically," said reviel netz, professor of ancient science at stanford university.the palimpsest disappeared between the time that heiberg studied it and the 1930s, when it resurfaced in a private collection in paris.on oct. 29, 1998, it was sold at christie's auction house in new york for $2 million. the anonymous owner of the manuscript has entrusted the document to the care of the walters for conservation and study.to reconstruct the original document, walters set up a competition to search for a team of scientists able to decipher the work. "we had lots of applications for the job globally and we whittled it down to two," noel said.the two winners were the rochester institute of technology (rit) and johns hopkins university.both teams were given five pages of the palimpsest to work from. "the five pages had a variety of problems -- faint text, mold -- one had a forgery on it," noel said.the manuscript was so badly damaged that traditional methods of imaging, using visible or ultraviolet light, proved ineffective."it's in terrible condition. it's had an awful lot of damage," noel said. "it's suffered from mold. it's animal skin, so it's very durable, but mold can damage it. it's also been in a fire; the edges are charred."the teams had the added problem of having to decipher the text without damaging the very frail parchment. "we can't remove material from the palimpsest," said johns hopkins' bill christens-barry. "it's very fragile, so we can't go into it or get in contact with it, so we have to use benign techniques."christens-barry's team used three main techniques to decipher the palimpsest. the first was multi-spectral imaging. "this involves the use of a very high-resolution digital camera together with a series of optical filters that allowed us to take images that broke up the visible light spectrum into a number of very narrow bands," he said.the team also used ultraviolet light to measure both the amount and wavelengths of the florescent emissions, which allowed them to build a 3-d matrix of data or a "spectral fingerprint" of the original ink.the second technique used was confocal microscopy, a technology more commonly used to probe the structure of cells in, among other things, cancer research."the unique capability of the confocal microscope is that it's able to do optical sectioning," christens-barry said. "it allows you to look in depth into the object and isolate a single layer while ignoring everything above and below it."this technique allowed the team to build up a record of the object as a 3-d object. "it's sort of a non-contact archeology in which we've looked at the deposition of different strata of the palimpsest," he said.in the third technique, the johns hopkins team examined light emitted by a fluorescent process, in which they looked at the amounts of light given off by the parchment.the ink used in the original archimedes text was iron gall ink, which is acidic and therefore corrodes the parchment. "in doing so, it modifies some of the molecules, the proteins and fats in the parchment so that when those molecules are excited by ultraviolet wavelengths the fluorescence they give off vary somewhat in color," christens-barry said.the clarity of the results achieved by the johns hopkins team depended on the quality of the page. "we only get a crystal-clear image when we're lucky. not only is the ink gone, but also there has been some diffusion of what was there in these residues -- so it's kind of smudged," he said.some sections of the text have been lost forever. "fortunately, there is a lot of context in greek, so that finding anything at all often makes it very easy for scholars to understand what the text refers to," christens-barry said.the rit team visited the walters gallery to take photographs of the five pages, also using a digital camera. the camera takes images in 1,536 x 1,024 pixels."the camera has a little refrigerator," said roger easton jr., a professor at chester f. carlson center for imaging at rit. "because it keeps the sensor cool you can get more gray levels. we can get 4,096 gray levels where most digital cameras only get 256."easton believes that, with a higher resolution camera, his team would be able to produce a fairly clear deciphering of the archimedes text. "i'd be very hesitant to say that we would get all of it ... but i think we've got a good chance of seeing some of it."the walters is still in the process of deciding which of the two teams, if either, will be awarded the project. "both teams did a truly spectacular job," noel said.despite the excitement generated by the research, scientists realize the project will take years. "the scholars are drooling over this," christens-barry said. "we've waited over 2,000 years to learn some of what archimedes was thinking and there will be one chance to do it and we want to make sure we take our time and do it correctly."
